<misra_rule>
MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.2 is: Functions shall not call themselves, either directly or indirectly.

</misra_rule>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- is_rule_violated: whether the rule is violated or not (true/false),
- scenario: a specific violation scenario.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UtBinFile2Mem:
```c
bool UtBinFile2Mem(void *Memory, const char *Filename, uint32 Length)
{
    FILE *fp;
    bool  Success;

    Success = false;
    if ((fp = fopen(Filename, "r")))
    {
        if (fread(Memory, Length, 1, fp) == 1)
        {
            Success = true;
        }
        fclose(fp);
    }
    else
    {
        UtAssert_Failed("UtBinFile2Mem: Error Opening %s: %s", Filename, strerror(errno));
    }

    return Success;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are close to the target function UtBinFile2Mem:

...

</additional code>
<target_code>
Here is the code fragment that you need to analyze:
```c
fclose(fp);
```
Focus on the above code fragment and judge whether it violates the rule 17.2 or not.
</target_code>
scenario: No violation: the call to fclose(fp) is a call to the C library function fclose. There is no evidence in the provided code that fclose (or any other called function such as fopen, fread, UtAssert_Failed/UtAssertEx, UtAssert_GetContext, strerror) calls UtBinFile2Mem, so no direct or indirect recursion exists. (Only if a nonstandard/custom implementation of fclose or one of the asserted handlers were to call back into UtBinFile2Mem would an indirect recursion be possible, but nothing in the supplied code shows that.)
